thread.title: Comedian Russell Brand bags Armadale and 'bogan West Coast fans' in Perth show
thread.title_full: Comedian Russell Brand bags Armadale and 'bogan West Coast fans' in Perth show

author: Heather McNeil
title: Comedian Russell Brand bags Armadale and 'bogan West Coast fans' in Perth show
text:
Russell Brand appears to be fond of WA's very own Nat Fyfe 
Like 'dipping your dick in custard' - Brand's saucy take on Turnbull Like many wise comedians before him, Russell Brand did his research on our humble city before performing his show at Perth Arena on Tuesday night.
His verdict?
West Coast Eagles fans are bogans, Armadale is a no-go zone, and Nat Fyfe's body is "gorgeous" and "ripped."
Advertisement While no one can  dispute his call on Nat Fyfe , one comment did leave the 5000-strong audience slightly puzzled.
"Perthlings, that's what you are called. Perthverts?" he said - Brand may want to check his sources on that call.
In between his hilarious, crass and sometimes philosophical interpretations of the media and society, Brand made time to stir up some home-town rivalries.
"Eagles and the Dockers - now typically one is a bit more bogan than the other I've found," he said.
"I'm guessing the Eagles is the bogan one from the early shouting [from the crowd]."The Aussie rules footy, f*cking hell everyone, it's a bit odd that the word rules is in the title when that seems to be the primary thing that is dispensed with, along with sleeves."
Just days after Brand's comments on Prime Minister Malcolm Turnball's Cayman Islands offshore investments made national headlines, the comedian did not hold back during the Perth leg of his Trew World Order show, making several jokes about the country's methamphetamine crisis.
"It ain't easy getting into your country," he said.
"[You're] unduly concerned about fruit getting in...'Have you got any fruit with you? Are you sure you haven't got any fruit?'
"Then you arrive and everyone's on meth - you need to reconsider your priorities."
Reading from a note scribbled on his hand, Brand also warned the audience about one of Perth's southern suburbs.
"Don't go Armadale," he said. "Bit dangerous there huh? Unless you explicitly require meth."
The night ended with one lucky Perth woman being offered a one-way flight back to England with the actor comedian. Audience member Katie had her phone taken by Brand while he was interacting with the crowd.
He later used it on stage to call her mother Ros and thank her "very warmly" for his new wife Katie, whose name he joked was "convenient" - presumably referring to his ex-wife and pop-star Katy Perry.
